summary: Experienced Clinical Pharmacist with experience in formulary, policy, and protocol development. Skilled in Hospital Pharmacy, U.S. Department of Defense, Navy, Operational Planning, and Organizational Leadership. Strong healthcare services professional graduated from UCSF.

currentPositions.description:
Provides comprehensive medication management for complex pain patients, including designing, implementing, assessing, monitoring, and documenting progress towards achievement of patient-centric, function-related goals, improving quality of life, and minimizing theoretical risk of drug-related harm.

Collaborates with interdisciplinary teams, including pain physicians/anesthesiologists, social workers, physical therapists, psychologists and other members of the Pain team to include non-medication modalities in total patient care.

Serves as the pharmacist subject matter expert on assigned pain management related committees and subcommittees for the Finger Lakes VA Health Care System.
currentPositions.title: Clinical Pharmacist Practitioner - Pain Management

educations.schoolName: United States Military Academy at West Point

headline: Clinical Pharmacist Practitioner - Pain Management at U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs

certifications.name: Joint Professional Military Education Phase I

publications.name: Evaluation of the effects of immediate release and extended release gabapentin on postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and pain in women undergoing hysterectomy.
publications.description:
Purpose: To evaluate the effects of immediate and extended release gabapentin on postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and pain in women undergoing hysterectomy.

Design: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

Methods: Ninety-two subjects were randomized to receive gabapentin immediate release 300mg, gabapentin enacarbil extended release 600mg, or a placebo pre-operatively. Post-operative pain and PONV were assessed using a 0-10 scale from arrival to the post-anesthesia care unit through the first 24 hours of hospital stay. Analgesic and antiemetic use was recorded. 

Findings: In post-hysterectomy women, gabapentin immediate release showed a statistically significant decrease in morphine equivalents at one hour postoperatively, with a trend toward decreased pain and PONV throughout the 24-hour stay.

Conclusions: Given the relatively low cost of immediate release gabapentin, minimal risks associated with this mediation, and potential benefit to patients, it should be considered as an appropriate adjunctive multimodal therapy for gynecology surgery patients.
publications.publisher: Submitted to Journal of PeriAnesthesia Nursing
